qas.question: What is the criteria for copyright?
What minor things can be included and not invalidate a copyright?

answers.text: The mere addition of a word, or substitution of a term with another one believed to be more correct

qas.question: Are footnotes included in the copyright of the original work?

answers.text: All the notes accounting for the analysis and why and how such changes have been made represent a different work autonomously copyrightable

qas.question: What rights do scientific publications in the EU enjoy?

answers.text: the relevant neighboring right that protects critical and scientific publications of public domain works

qas.question: What does not matter in order to be copyrighted?

plausible_answers.text: The mere addition of a word, or substitution of a term with another one believed to be more correct

qas.question: What minor things can be included and validate a copyright?
Non-scientific editions can be protected by what?
What are not protected by copyright?
All EU member states have transposed what into law?

context: <b7_0>Scientific and critical editions<b7_0/> can be protected by <b6_0>copyright<b6_0/> as works of authorship <a0_0>if enough <b4_0>creativity/originality is provided<b4_0/><a0_0/>. <a1_0><b5_0>The mere addition of a word, or substitution of a term with another one believed to be more correct<b5_0/><a1_0/>, usually does not achieve such level of originality/creativity. <a2_0>All the notes accounting for the analysis and why and how such changes have been made represent a different work autonomously copyrightable<a2_0/> if the other requirements are satisfied. In the European Union critical and scientific editions may be protected also by <a3_0>the relevant neighboring right that protects critical and scientific publications of public domain works<a3_0/> as made possible by art. 5 of the Copyright Term Directive. Not all EU member States have transposed <b8_0>art. 5<b8_0/> into national law.
